title: General Paper FQE (Jan 2022)
description: Final Qualifying Examination General Paper from January 2022. Contains 52 questions covering Psychology, Mental Health, Pediatrics, Nursing Education, and Research.

questions.question: The aims of psychology include:
questions.explanation: The four main goals of psychology are to Describe, Explain, Predict, and Control (or Influence) behavior.

questions.question: A person with avoidant personality disorder has pervasive pattern of:
questions.explanation: Avoidant Personality Disorder is characterized by social inhibition, feelings of inadequacy, and hypersensitivity to negative evaluation.

questions.question: Early signs of increased intracranial pressure in an infant include:

options.text: Crying when held, distended scalp veins, coma
High pitched cry, headache, and changes in feeding
Bulging fontanelles, crying when held, increased occipital frontal circumference
Increased occipital frontal circumference, drowsiness, coma

questions.explanation: In infants, open fontanelles allow the head to expand (increased circumference) and bulge to accommodate pressure. Irritability (crying when held) is an early sign.

questions.question: Feeding recommendation for a child 2 years and above is:

options.text: Given enriched family foods 3 times a day with a least two snacks in between
Given enriched family foods 3 times a day avoid snacks in between
Given enriched family foods 2 times a day with a least three snacks in between
Given enriched family foods 3 times a day start introducing complementary feeds

questions.explanation: WHO recommendations for children >2 years include 3 meals of family foods plus 2 snacks daily.

questions.question: After initiating treatment for a child with classification of pneumonia the guardian is counseled to:

options.text: Give treatment and wait for return date
Come back to the facility immediately if the child become worse
Seek senior review at a higher facility
Reduce amount of clothes and give prescribed medication

questions.explanation: Counseling on 'When to return immediately' (if child worsens, can't drink, fast breathing) is a critical IMCI step.

questions.question: Which disease is related with total energy depletion where individuals are alert, ravenous with very high appetite and very irritable?
questions.explanation: Marasmus (wasting) is total calorie depletion. Children are often alert and hungry, unlike the apathetic/anorexic child with Kwashiorkor.

questions.question: In nutritional assessment of children, acute malnutrition is indicated by:

options.text: Height for weight Z score and MUAC
Weight for age Z score and MUAC
Weight for height Z score and MUAC

questions.explanation: Acute malnutrition (wasting) is assessed via Weight-for-Height (WHZ) or Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC).

questions.question: In order to identify and minimize trauma to a child, the nurse should:

options.text: Avoid separation of child and mother, explain procedure, give chance to express feelings
Avoid separation, explain procedure, avoid unpleasant procedures
Separate child and mother during painful procedure, explain procedure...
Separate child and mother to reduce panic...

questions.explanation: Atraumatic care principles emphasize preventing family separation and providing control/explanation.

questions.question: The commonest type of hallucination in an alcoholic patient is:
questions.explanation: Visual hallucinations (e.g., seeing small animals/bugs) are hallmark features of alcohol withdrawal delirium.

questions.question: Which of the following actions indicates a need for FURTHER health messages to parents of a child with congenital heart defect?

options.text: Counting the number of wet diapers to monitor fluid levels
Listening to pulse for one minute while giving digoxin at home
Protecting the child from people with upper respiratory infections
Waking up the child for feeding every 2 hours to help gain weight

questions.explanation: Children with CHD need rest to conserve energy. Frequent waking increases fatigue and cardiac workload. They should feed on demand or schedules that allow rest.

questions.question: In curriculum development, the 'must learn' indicates:

options.text: Tasks that broaden the profession in a work set up
Tasks the learner performs in an educational program
Tasks which the learner has to know and perform
Tasks to be learnt in the syllabus

questions.explanation: 'Must learn' tasks are the core competencies essential for safe practice.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding visual learners?

options.text: Benefit from using charts, maps, notes, and flash cards when studying
Do not prefer to see information such as pictures, diagrams, cartoons
Learn best when intense visuals accompanied by lecture
Not easily distracted in lecture with no visual aids

questions.explanation: Visual learners prefer seeing information (charts, maps, text).

questions.question: In an objective, a description of the subject reference which could be knowledge, attitude or skills is:
questions.explanation: The content reference describes the specific subject matter being learned.

questions.question: A neurotransmitter that mediates sleepiness and wakefulness is:
questions.explanation: Serotonin is a key regulator of the sleep-wake cycle and mood.

questions.question: In research, an in-depth investigation of an individual, group, institution or phenomena is called:
questions.explanation: Case studies involve intensive, detailed analysis of a single unit.

questions.question: Attitudes are best learnt through:
questions.explanation: Attitudes (Affective domain) are learned socially and experientially, not via lectures.

questions.question: The main difference between experimental and non-experimental studies in research is:

options.text: The researcher is a passive observer in non-experimental study
The researcher manipulates the independent variable in non-experimental study
The researcher is an active agent in experimental study
The researcher manipulates the dependent variable in experimental study

questions.explanation: In experimental studies, the researcher is an active agent who manipulates the independent variable.

questions.question: In order to minimize a type II error in research the researcher should:
questions.explanation: Increasing sample size increases statistical power, reducing the risk of missing a real effect (Type II error).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a factor to consider when choosing a research design?
questions.explanation: Statistical significance is a result of analysis, not a factor for choosing the design beforehand.

questions.question: Which part of the research process helps the researcher to narrow the research topic and determine new approaches?
questions.explanation: Literature review identifies gaps and refines the scope of the study.

questions.question: An instructional objective is stated in terms of:
questions.explanation: Objectives must describe what the learner will do.

questions.question: In the cognitive domain of learning, the learner is expected to gain:
questions.explanation: Cognitive = Knowledge/Thinking.

questions.question: In order to overcome their own anxieties in dealing with the patient, the nurse should:

options.text: Go through their record, Talk to the clinical supervisor or other nurses about their fears
Set her goals very clearly, Plan a long interaction with the patient
Go through their record, avoid talking to the clinical supervisor
Avoid talking to the clinical supervisor, plan a brief interaction

questions.explanation: Self-awareness and mentorship/supervision are key to managing countertransference and anxiety.

questions.question: A symptom where the patient has lengthy and tedious verbalizations and because of numerous details they NEVER reach the intended point is referred to as:
questions.explanation: Tangentiality = Never reaches the point. Circumstantiality = Takes a long time but eventually reaches the point.

questions.question: Which of the following is a negative symptom in schizophrenia?

options.text: Flat affect: separation from external world
Excessive or additional to normal thoughts

questions.explanation: Negative symptoms represent deficits in normal function (e.g., flat affect, avolition).

questions.question: In treatment of depression, tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) work by:

options.text: Blocking reuptake of norepinephrine at post-synaptic terminals
Blocking reuptake of norepinephrine at pre-synaptic terminals
Increasing reuptake of norepinephrine at pre-synaptic terminals
Increasing reuptake of norepinephrine at post-synaptic terminals

questions.explanation: TCAs block the reuptake pumps on the pre-synaptic neuron, increasing neurotransmitter availability.

questions.question: Motivation associated with activities that are their own reward is:
questions.explanation: Intrinsic motivation is driven by internal satisfaction.

questions.question: In behaviorism, an attractive object or event supplied as a consequence of behavior is:
questions.explanation: A reward (positive reinforcer) follows behavior to increase its frequency.

questions.question: A goal to improve and to learn is:
questions.explanation: Mastery goals focus on competence and learning. Performance goals focus on grades/winning.

questions.question: A learner who prefers to see information such as pictures, diagrams, and cartoons is:
questions.explanation: Visual learners learn best by seeing.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a nursing diagnosis for a patient who is suicidal?

options.text: Risk for injury related to recent suicide attempt
Risk for injury to others related to stated desire to end it all and recent purchase of a handgun

questions.explanation: 'Risk for injury to OTHERS' is a diagnosis for homicidal/aggressive patients, not specifically for suicide (self-harm).

questions.question: In tertiary prevention of mental illness, the focus is on:

options.text: Management of individuals with severe and persistent mental illness

questions.explanation: Tertiary prevention involves rehabilitation and reducing disability in established illness.

questions.question: The fear of places or situations that might cause embarrassment (e.g., panic in public) is:
questions.explanation: Agoraphobia is the fear of places where escape is difficult or help unavailable, often linked to fear of embarrassment.

questions.question: A patient brought to the hospital by a senior police officer and relative against their will is admitted as:
questions.explanation: Admission without consent is Involuntary.

questions.question: Which of the following will help reduce bias in research?

options.text: Use of multiple people to code the data
Review findings with peers, Use of multiple people to code the data
Not allowing participants review your results

questions.explanation: Peer review and triangulation (multiple coders) reduce researcher bias.

questions.question: The type of bias that occurs when samples under-represent certain groups and over-represent others is:
questions.explanation: Selection bias results from unrepresentative sampling.

questions.question: In nephrotic syndrome, proteinuria can be explained to be as a result of:

options.text: Changes in permeability of the glomerular membrane
Increase in osmotic pressure of the blood

questions.explanation: Glomerular damage increases permeability, allowing protein leakage.

questions.question: Secondary or existing data may include which of the following?
questions.explanation: Personal documents/records are existing data. Questionnaires/Focus groups collect new (primary) data.

questions.question: A child with disorientation of time, place, and person is said to be:
questions.explanation: Disorientation describes confusion regarding time, place, or person.

questions.question: In children with poisoning:

options.text: Induced emesis is contraindicated in hydrocarbon poisoning
Induced emesis is contraindicated in all poisons
Gastric lavage is contraindicated in all poisons
Gastric lavage can be performed at home

questions.explanation: Inducing vomiting in hydrocarbon poisoning (e.g., paraffin) risks aspiration pneumonia.

questions.question: State one advantage and one disadvantage of Simulation as a teaching method.
acceptedAnswers: Advantage: No risk to patients, Disadvantage: Time consuming
questions.explanation: Advantage: Practice in safe environment. Disadvantage: Cost/Time.

questions.question: Explain two purposes of literature review.
State four theoretical foundations of learning.
State four functions of the mental health board.
State four components of chapter three (Methodology) of a research report.
List four (4) attributes of video as a media in teaching.
State the five side effects of antipsychotics.
State two (2) methods of stimulus variation in teaching.
State five nursing care management steps for a patient with depression.
Outline four purposes of research.
Distinguish between qualitative and quantitative research.

pairs.right: Deals with numbers, statistics, objective data, and hypothesis testing
Deals with words, meanings, subjective experiences, and descriptions

questions.question: Case Study: Infantile Convulsions. Select correct definition, causes, complications, and management.

options.text: Def: Involuntary muscular contractions with loss of consciousness
Mgmt: Safety (Do not restrain, move sharp objects)
Mgmt: Airway (Recovery position, suction if needed)
Mgmt: Place tongue depressor in mouth
